There was no formal program for the dinner. Following
dinner Hull introduced Dr. Charles E. Friley, President
Emeritus, Iowa State College, who spoke briefly.
Dr. Friley restated his basic faith in the educational
opportunity which is afforded by educational radio and
television. He cited the increasing complexity of modern
day life and the fact that no one can be expected to beÂ¬
come expert in or even to have a fair working knowledge
of all factors which impinge upon his personal life or
the society in general. It is in an attempt to fill in
these gaps that educational broadcasting has its greatest
opportunity and challenge, and Dr. Friley expressed
optimism that educational broadcasting will increasingly
meet this challenge.
